question: Question_01_(a)
sols:
The answer is iv.

At the point of \emph{x=0}, \emph{G(0)=0} because the top and bottom
limits of the integral that defines \emph{G(x)} are identical. The area
that is integrated over has zero width.

At the point of \emph{x=2}, \emph{G(2)=2} because the area of the graph
can be calculated using the area of triangle formula \emph{height*base/2
= 2*2/2 =2}

At the point of \emph{x=4}, \emph{G(4)=-2} because the area between the
\emph{x}-axis and the graph \emph{g(x)} is composed of two triangles
with height \emph{4} and width \emph{1}. Hence the area is given by
\emph{4*1/2 + 4*1/2 = 4}. It is below the \emph{x}-axis, hence we
subtract it from the previous value and get \emph{G(4) = 2 - 4 = -2}.

At the point \emph{x=6}, \emph{G(6)=0} because we add the area of the
triangle with height \emph{2} and width \emph{2} to the previous value:
\emph{G(6) = -2 + 2*2/2 = 0}

At the point \emph{x=8}, \emph{G(8)=4} because we add the area of the
square with height \emph{2} and width \emph{2} to the previous value:
\emph{G(8) = 0 + 2*2 = 4}
hints:
Substitute \emph{x} with the values given in the table. Calculate the
area of \emph{g(x)} with basic geometry formula, i.e. area of triangle
and area of a square.

The substituted values of \emph{x} should be 2, 4, 6, 8, as at these
points the area under the graph of \emph{g(x)} can be calculated with
the area of triangle formula: base*height/2
Area below the \emph{x}-axis has to be subtracted from the net area.
